## Statistics Lab: One-Sample t-Test

### Objective

Students will:
	‚Ä¢	Conduct and interpret a one-sample t-test in R (or another platform you prefer).
	‚Ä¢	Compare their sample data to a known or hypothesized population mean.
	‚Ä¢	Communicate their findings in APA-style format.

## 1. Concept Refresher (5‚Äì10 minutes)

Prompt:
‚ÄúSometimes we want to know if a group we‚Äôre studying is different from the general population ‚Äî but we only have one group‚Äôs data. The one-sample t-test helps us test whether our sample mean differs significantly from a known or hypothesized mean.‚Äù

Example questions to warm up:
	‚Ä¢	What does the t-test compare?
	‚Ä¢	What does the null hypothesis say in this context?
	‚Ä¢	How does sample size affect the t statistic?

## 2. Example Scenario Ideas (Pick one or rotate by section)

Each scenario includes a population mean and invites students to test a claim:

Theme	Scenario	Population Mean (Œº‚ÇÄ)	Variable Example
üç´ Fun & Food	The average American eats 12 pounds of chocolate per year. Is our class different?	12	chocolate_pounds
üì± Technology	On average, college students spend 4 hours/day on their phone. Is our sample higher?	4	hours_per_day
üí§ Sleep	The CDC recommends 8 hours of sleep per night. Does our sample get less?	8	sleep_hours
üò¨ Anxiety	National anxiety scale mean = 50 (SD = 10). Is our class more anxious?	50	anxiety_score

## 3. Data Collection (10‚Äì15 minutes)

Option 1: Live data collection
Have students submit quick responses via Google Form or Qualtrics (e.g., ‚ÄúHow many hours of sleep did you get last night?‚Äù). Export as a .csv.

Step 1: State hypotheses


Step 3: Interpret the output
	‚Ä¢	t-value

Step 4: APA write-up example

Students in our sample (M = 7.2, SD = 0.9) reported significantly less sleep than the CDC‚Äôs recommended 8 hours, t(29) = -4.67, p < .001.

## 5. Discussion Questions
	1.	What does the negative t-value indicate?
	2.	What would happen if the sample were larger but had the same mean?
	3.	How does the confidence interval help confirm your conclusion?
	4.	Can a non-significant result still be meaningful? Why or why not?

## 6. Optional Extension

## Deliverable

A short lab report (or RMarkdown/Quarto doc) including:
	1.	Stated hypotheses
	2.	Output and interpretation
	3.	APA-style results section
	4.	Visual (optional)
	5.	Reflection question: ‚ÄúWhat does your result suggest about your sample?‚Äù

<script>
  // htmlwidgets need to know to resize themselves when slides are shown/hidden.
  // Fire the "slideenter" event (handled by htmlwidgets.js) when the current
  // slide changes (different for each slide format).
  (function () {
    // dispatch for htmlwidgets
    function fireSlideEnter() {
      const event = window.document.createEvent("Event");
      event.initEvent("slideenter", true, true);
      window.document.dispatchEvent(event);
    }

    function fireSlideChanged(previousSlide, currentSlide) {
      fireSlideEnter();

      // dispatch for shiny
      if (window.jQuery) {
        if (previousSlide) {
          window.jQuery(previousSlide).trigger("hidden");
        }
        if (currentSlide) {
          window.jQuery(currentSlide).trigger("shown");
        }
      }
    }

    // hookup for slidy
    if (window.w3c_slidy) {
      window.w3c_slidy.add_observer(function (slide_num) {
        // slide_num starts at position 1
        fireSlideChanged(null, w3c_slidy.slides[slide_num - 1]);
      });
    }

  })();
</script>
